Content_title: Mikel Arteta admits Arsenal took ‘risk’ with Alexandre Lacazette contract talks but reveals hope for captain’s Gunners future despite Lyon return rumours
Contents: Arsenal manager Mikel Arteta admits the club took a risk by allowing Alexandre Lacazette’s contract to run down. The France striker’s current deal expires at the end of the campaign and he looks set to depart the north London club after confirming talks with other clubs, with a return to Lyon on the cards. Lacazette recently revealed said he was ‘in discussions with a lot of clubs’ and said he ‘misses playing in the Champions League’, in a recent interview with French outlet Canal Plus . When asked if he was surprised by his captain’s comments, Arteta said: “Well he doesn’t need to tell me what he does in his own life but he has, we have discussed that and he is entitled to do that – then he has a duty to do his best here. “His contract situation allows him to make the decision about his future. We have expressed clearly what our intention is – to speak in the summer once we know where we are, about what we are going to do in the future together. “And for the rest, I just want him fully focused on his duty, which is now defend Arsenal in the best possible way, like he has done all the time he has been with us. That’s why he has been wearing the armband of this football club, that’s a big reason. “The contracts start and end with the expiry date that you have agreed on that day that you put the pen down. “Then you have to deal with the consequences with that and that’s the reality of the contract that he has, and the commitment and the duty that he has with the football club.”  Arsenal face a tough test against Chelsea on Wednesday, with their top four hopes hanging in the balance. Lacazette will not feature in the match after testing positive for COVID-19. The Gunners boss, however, remains optimistic his star striker will remain at the club beyond the summer and snub other clubs’ advances. “It is the agreement that we made with him, that was our position and our position remains the same, that is what we are going to do,” Arteta said. “The risk of that happening, it was always there since the moment we made that decision, then it is up to him. It is not up to us or him it is up to both parties.” Arteta also said Arsenal’s summer transfer business will depend on whether they qualify for next seasons Champions League.  “Champions League brings, first of all, the club much closer to where we want and to play in a competition that has a huge history in relation to our club,” he added. “Secondly, obviously it improves every situation with the sponsor, financially, expectations, the capacity to grow our players and expose them into a different dimension of a competition and this is where we want to be. “It is a game-changer. Content_title: Darwin Nunez responds to transfer reports with Liverpool, Manchester United and Arsenal linked with £65million-rated Benfica striker
Contents: Benfica sensation Darwin Nunez has responded to transfer speculation with three Premier League clubs showing their interest in the £60million-rated striker. Liverpool, Manchester United and Arsenal are reportedly amongst the clubs keeping tabs on Nunez ahead of a potential summer bidding war for his signature. Liverpool advanced to the Champions League semi-finals with a 6-4 aggregate win over the Portuguese outfit on Wednesday, with Nunez again impressing despite his side crashing out. His stunning performances this term have attracted a host of suitors ahead of the summer transfer window, with Tottenham and Newcastle United also reportedly interested in bringing him to the Premier League. Should Nunez get his big move abroad this summer then Benfica will certainly command a whopping transfer fee for their prized asset who is contracted to the Lisbon giants until June 2025. Benfica manager Nelson Verissimo claimed Nunez should be valued at a similar fee to Joao Felix who departed for Atletico Madrid for £113m in 2019, but there is a feeling that the figure will be more around the £65m Benfica valued him at when he was linked with a move away in January. With Liverpool said to be one of the clubs tracking the 22-year-old, Jurgen Klopp was full of praise for the Uruguayan who has been attracting the attention of Europe’s top clubs. “Extremely good-looking boy and a decent player as well,“ said Klopp of the 22-year-old striker, who plundered two goals across the tie.  “Really good, really good, I have to say. I knew him before, of course but he played pretty much in front of me with these tough battles with Ibou Konate. “Physically strong, quick, was calm with his finish when he finished the goal off. Good, really good. If he stays healthy, it’s a big career ahead of him.” Scorer of Benfica’s third goal in Wednesday’s 3-3 draw at Anfield, Nunez remained tight-lipped after the match in response to Klopp’s comments and reiterated his desire to focus on finishing the season strong for the Lisbon-based club. Darwin Núñez scores another goal in the Champions League! 🔥The young star continues to shine against Europe's elite clubs…What a star 💫 #UCL pic.twitter.com/hzEZAwjoI8 “What the Liverpool coach said, I take it as a compliment, but my mind is on Benfica,” Nunez told Portuguese broadcaster TVI. “I won’t say anything, and I’ll leave everything for this shirt. My job is to continue like this, to take advantage of this luck that is happening to me. “Last year I didn’t play at all, but this year I’m having an incredible season. I have to continue like this, and there is also a lot of merit from my colleagues.” Nunez has found the net 24 times in 20 starts in the Portuguese top flight and six goals in six Champions League appearances including two against both Liverpool and Barcelona and one against Bayern Munich. Content_title: Antonio Rudiger accused of bottling Karim Benzema battle to ‘avoid injury that could hamper potential transfer’, as former Chelsea star says defender ‘could have done more’ to stop Real Madrid hat-trick hero
Contents: Antonio Rudiger has been accused of having a potential summer transfer away from Chelsea in mind as he bottled his battle with Real Madrid striker Karim Benzema. The Blues centre-back was guilty of a poor ‘half-challenge’ on French star Benzema, which allowed him to score his hat-trick goal in the 3-1 win at Stamford Bridge. In the quarter-final of the Champions League, trophy holders Chelsea locked horns with the Spanish giants looking to make the most of having the first-leg at home. But the game did not go to plan, as Benzema once again showcased his importance to the 13-time winners despite his age. The 34-year-old, who Real boss Carlo Ancelotti is ‘ageing like a fine wine’, netted a hat-trick which included two outstanding headers in the space of three first-half minutes. There was an element of fortunate for his goal that secured the match ball, as Blues goalkeeper Edouard Mendy and Rudiger had a calamitous moment. After the ball fell to him following a clearance from a Real player, 30-year-old goalkeeper Mendy had time and options to clear the ball. But his pass to the German defender was far too light, and it gave Benzema the chance to steal the ball.  Whilst it was a poor pass from the AFCON winning shot-stopper, Rudiger  had the chance of bailing his goalkeeper out. But his tackle was not strong enough to dispossess Benzema, who then had the simple task of placing the ball into an empty net. Speaking on Thursday’s talkSPORT Breakfast, Gabby Agbonlahor gave his thoughts and believed Rudiger was thinking about a potential transfer this summer and pulled out of a tough tackle to avoid any kind of injury. “I know it was a bad pass on Mendy, but Rudiger’s tackle was someone who didn’t want to get injured,” said the former Aston Villa captain. “It was like he’s got a move ready and he didn’t want to hurt himself.”  Former Chelsea defender Mario Melchiot didn’t completely agree with that statement, but did agree that Rudiger could have done more to stop the rampant Frenchman. “I can’t really say that, because he’s normally so tough, he does not care about that,” Melchiot told talkSPORT. “But the way he went in it, I agree with you, he could have gone tougher. “And he went with his left foot instead of his right and normally if you make the tackle with your right, and you go all the way [you would win the ball].  “Everything was half, half ball, half challenge, and that’s why Benzema [scored].” Rudiger is out of contract at Chelsea this summer and has been widely linked with an exit from Stamford Bridge at the end of the season. The Germany international is reportedly wanted by a host of suitors, with Real Madrid and Paris Saint-Germain the main contenders, although it has been claimed Manchester United could look to keep him in the Premier League by offering Rudiger a move to Old Trafford. Content_title: Unhappy Cristiano Ronaldo ‘will quit Manchester United’ if Red Devils fail to qualify for Champions League next season
Contents: Cristiano Ronaldo is reportedly set to leave Manchester United this summer unless they qualify for the Champions League. The Portugal sensation responded angrily to being substituted at Brentford on Wednesday night, with the Red Devils 2-0 up on 72 minutes. Ralf Rangnick’s men went on to win 3-1 and the United boss downplayed the incident after the match, but reports suggest all is not well with Ronaldo at Old Trafford. The 36-year-old returned to his old club on a two-year deal last summer and, despite a promising start, United are now clinging onto hopes of a top-four finish. According to The Sun, Ronaldo’s camp have held conversations with incoming chief executive Richard Arnold about cutting the forward’s second United spell short. It is understood Ronaldo wants to play until he is 40, but considers Champions League football an absolute minimum.  The five-time Ballon d’Or winner expected United to challenge for football’s top honours upon his return and a recent interview suggested he is disappointed with the current mentality at Old Trafford. “Manchester Unitedshould win the league or finish in second or third. I don’t see any other positions for Manchester United,” Ronaldo toldSky Sports. “In my head I don’t accept that our mentality be that we finish below the top three in the Premier League. “We are capable of changing things now… I know the way but I’m not going to mention here because I don’t think it’s etiquette on my part to say but what I can say is that we can do it better, all of us.  “We have to change that. I don’t want to be in a club where we fight to be in sixth, seventh or fifth place, I’m here to try to win, to compete. “I think we compete but we are not yet in our best level. We have a long way to improve but I believe if we change our mind we can achieve big things.” Rangnick’s men are currently seventh in the top-flight and need to make up ground on Arsenal, Tottenham and West Ham if they want to finish fourth.
